results.title: Excalibur
results.creator_credit: Orion Pictures Corporation and John Boorman
results.brief_description: The story of King Arthur and the Knights of the Round Table has inspired people for centuries. Arthur (Nigel Terry) has removed the magic sword Excalibur from the sacred stone and sets out to reunite the land as its King. Helen Mirren is the beautiful but sinister Morganna, Arthur’s half-sister, and Nicol Williamson is Merlin. This timeless tale includes the search for the Holy Grail and the tragic love of Guinevere and Lancelot. Cast also includes Nicholas Clay, Cherie Lunghi, Paul Geoffrey.

results.title: Examination of an unconscious patient
results.brief_description: This program demonstrates basic precautions to be undertaken when an accident has occurred. “Examination Of An Unconscious Patient” is an excellent basic level First Aid training resource, designed specifically for the training of non-medical personnel and conforming to Australian Resuscitation Council Standards.

results.title: Examination of a Patient
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Support”.
The procedure for a full head to toe examination of a patient. Utilising a common accident scene the program shows the steps required in handling an unconscious patient before medical help arrives.

results.title: Exam technique: economics
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Economics”.
Offers specialised exam preparation advice for economics students. Discusses the weeks prior to the exam, strategies for the night before, format and use of time in the exam itself, multiple choice and short answer questions and essay choice and planning.

results.title: Ex Nilalang
results.brief_description:
Ex Nilalang is a cumulative moving image project by Australian-Filipino collective Club Ate, founded by multidisciplinary video and performance artists, Justin Shoulder and Bhenji Ra. Three episodes were created in 2015 and ACMI is proud to have commissioned the fourth for Asia TOPA.

The work seeks to transform existing Filipino mythologies that were once used to demonise queer identities by colonial powers. ‘Nilalang’, which means both ‘to create’ and ‘creature’, describes the work’s transformation of existing mythologies and its imagining of future folklore.

The artists draw from their own narratives, lived experiences and personal relationships to forge new connections between queer, migrant, spiritual and intercultural experiences.

This latest video portrait will also screen alongside the first three episodes ‘Balud’, ‘Dyesebel’ and ‘Lolo ex Machina’ in ACMI’s cinemas as part of its regular ART+FILM program on Wednesday 1 March at 6.30pm, followed by a conversation with Justin Shoulder and Bhenji Ra.

The artists draw from their own narratives, lived experiences and personal relationships to forge new connections between queer, migrant, spiritual and intercultural experiences.

This latest video portrait will also screen alongside the first three episodes ‘Balud’, ‘Dyesebel’ and ‘Lolo ex Machina’ in ACMI’s cinemas as part of its regular ART+FILM program on Wednesday 1 March at 6.30pm, followed by a conversation with Justin Shoulder and Bhenji Ra.

The work seeks to transform existing Filipino mythologies that were once used to demonise queer identities by colonial powers. ‘Nilalang’, which means both ‘to create’ and ‘creature’, describes the work’s transformation of existing mythologies and its imagining of future folklore.

The artists draw from their own narratives, lived experiences and personal relationships to forge new connections between queer, migrant, spiritual and intercultural experiences.

This latest video portrait will also screen alongside the first three episodes ‘Balud’, ‘Dyesebel’ and ‘Lolo ex Machina’ in ACMI’s cinemas as part of its regular ART+FILM program on Wednesday 1 March at 6.30pm, followed by a conversation with Justin Shoulder and Bhenji Ra.

production_dates.notes:
This project is supported by the KMATS Endowment Fund and Arts Centre Melbourne for Asia TOPA.

Asia TOPA is a joint initiative of the Sidney Myer Fund and Arts Centre Melbourne and is supported by the Australian and Victorian Governments.

results.title: Evonne Goolagong Cawley crowns Ash Barty Australian Open champion
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of @AustralianOpen Twitter post
results.brief_description: Ngarigo woman and world number one in women’s singles tennis, Ash Barty, accepts the Daphne Akhurst Memorial Cup after a two-set victory in her Australian Open finals match against Danielle Collins. The trophy was bestowed on her by former world number one, Wiradjuri tennis legend Evonne Goolagong Cawley, who was crowned women’s singles champion at the Australian Open four years running, from 1974-77.
results.title_for_label: Evonne Goolagong Cawley crowns champion Ash Barty at the Australian Open
results.description: Ngarigo woman and women’s tennis world number one Ash Barty accepts the Daphne Akhurst Memorial Cup after a two-set victory in the Australian Open final against Danielle Collins. The trophy was bestowed on her by former world number one, Wiradjuri tennis legend Evonne Goolagong Cawley, who was crowned women’s singles champion at the Australian Open four years running, from 1974-77.

results.title: Evolutionary fantasy: Bolero by Maurice Ravel from Allegro n
results.creator_credit: Bruno Bozzetto Films and Bruno Bozzetto
results.brief_description: In this animated segment from the feature film “Allegro non troppo”. Ravel’s “Bolero” accompanies a satiric fantasy of the evolution of life beginning with an amoebic blob emerging from a coke bottle.
